Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Wave driven flow through a shallow, fringing reef
Award.AbstractNarration:
Coral reefs face two significant long-term challenges to their existence: (1) Ocean acidification, which hinders the ability of corals to calcify; and (2) Ocean warming, which leads to coral bleaching. The Ofu reef (American Samoa), home to corals that seem to have exceptional bleaching resistance, is the location of active research into how corals may be able to meet those challenges biologically and biogeochemically. Given that both carbon system and temperature dynamics on the reef depend on flow, the physical insights and quantitative results from the data and modeling of this study should provide significant input to studies of ecology and biogeochemistry at Ofu and other similar reefs. In addition, the project will advance the technology for mapping reefs at high resolution. The project will involve several undergraduate and graduate students, as well as a postdoctoral scientist, providing unique material for university courses. The results of this study will be brought to the general public through a series of short online videos, produced to explain the link between hydrodynamic processes and reef health.

The goals of this project are: (1) Test the concept that the relative importance of friction in the lagoon and friction on the reef crest determines the structure of the overall circulation; (2) Test the hypothesis that drag coefficients related to local, spatially averaged, flows can be estimated from data on reef topography; (3) Carry out a quantitative evaluation of the dynamics of Ofu reef flows using a depth-averaged circulation model based on detailed bathymetry and estimates of spatially variable drag parameterizations. The primary activities of this project would be: (a) Mapping of reef bathymetry at decimeter scale using an Unmanned Aerial Vehicle carrying cameras and novel image processing of the resulting images; (b) Deploying a set pressure loggers, temperature loggers, acoustic Doppler current profilers and a meteorological station for a 2-km long section of the Ofu reef for two one-month periods and analyzing the results of these observations to estimate flow properties such as drag; (c) Idealized and realistic modeling studies carried out using a three dimensional model. The design of the instrument array in combination with the mapping and modeling is intended to both test the conceptual circulation model and to evaluate how drag on different parts of the reef varies with overall depth, flow and with geometric parameters describing the physical structure of the reef.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Fluid flow over coral reefs is known to strongly influence the ability of corals to withstand the potentially fatal effects of high water temperatures and, more generally, can influence a wide variety of ecological and chemical processes including calcification. This project focused on understanding the connection between the topography of a coral reef, i.e., the complex surface created by the community of corals found on the reef, and the drag this topography creates. This is important because the strength of flows over coral reefs is almost always controlled by friction associated with turbulence generated by the corals themselves. 

 

This project focused on studying flows on and through the reef lagoon system found on Ofu, American Samoa, where flows are driven by incident surface waves. In 2016 and 2017, waves, water levels, temperatures and currents were measured both in the shallow lagoon and on the offshore forereef using a dense suite of current meters, pressure loggers, and temperature recorders. To measure the topography a camera mounted on a commercial unmanned aerial vehicle (AUV, aka a drone) was used to image the reef. These images were converted to topography and formed the basis of a high-resolution 3D model of flow over several sections of the reef, a model that was verified by comparison with the in situ observations. This work shows that drag is primarily created by separation of flow around larger coral structures, meaning that AUV-derived reef geometry can be used as a basis for computing frictional drag on reefs. Moreover, the behavior of drag on reefs was found to be consistent with that of other rough surfaces like sand dunes in rivers.

 

Besides addressing the primary objective of connecting reef geometry with drag, this project also examined the interaction of tidal water level variations and wave-driven flows, finding that the interaction between wave breaking on the fore-reef and depth of water on the reef flat strongly influences the strength of flows throughout the system. This is important because overall these flows determine temperature variability in the Ofu lagoon and thus the likelihood of coral bleaching and the extent to which the reef may recover from bleaching episodes. 

 

Finally, this project supported a small undergraduate research project in Palau looking at the related problem of drag on a seagrass bed, behavior that is important to the ecology of seagrass communities and to the ability of seagrass beds to sequester carbon and influence local water pH (acididty). These measurements, made with the same suite of instruments used on Ofu show that flow-dependent drag can be computed using an existing model of seagrass flows that incorporates flexibility of the seagrass as well as knowledge of the species of seagrass, number of plants per square meter, and the height of individual seagrass blades. 

 

Overall, this project shows the clear, predictable connection between the geometry of the organisms found in shallow coastal ecosystems like reefs and seagrasses and the flows through those ecosystems. Given that these flows are themselves important to shaping the ecological functioning of reefs, seagrass beds etc., the results of this project should be important to protecting, restoring, and managing these important ecosystems.
